Back: A course that studies how media products are made, used and interpreted.
The codes and conventions used to create meaning in media products.
How people, places and ideas are shown in the media.
How media is produced, distributed and regulated.
How audiences are targeted, reached and respond to media.
A text such as a film, advert, magazine, website or game.
Any media product that can be analysed for meaning.
How producers put meaning into a media product.
How audiences interpret meaning from a media product.

Front: What is Stuart Hall's reception theory?
Back: Producers encode meanings; audiences decode them in different ways.
The meaning the producer wants the audience to accept.
Partly agrees with the preferred meaning but questions some parts.
Rejects the preferred meaning and interprets it differently.
The intended group a media product is made for.
Dividing audiences by factors like age, gender, lifestyle and income.
Audience data such as age, gender, class, location.
Audience lifestyle, values, attitudes and interests.

Front: What is the NRS social grade system?
Back: A UK audience class system from A to E.
A category of media product with typical features.
Typical features audiences expect in a genre.
A media product that combines genres.
The way a story is structured and told.
Events are shown in chronological order.
Story is not told in time order.
A mystery that makes the audience want to keep watching.
An ending that creates suspense and encourages audiences to continue.
The main character the story follows.
A character or force opposing the protagonist.
A contrast between two opposites, like good and evil.
Equilibrium, disruption, recognition, attempt to repair, new equilibrium.

Front: What is Levi-Strauss theory in media?
Back: Meaning is created through binary oppositions.

Front: What is Barthes' theory of codes?
Back: Enigma and action codes help create meaning and narrative.
Everything in the shot: setting, costume, lighting, props, actors.
Camera work like shot types, angles and movement.
How shots are arranged to create meaning and pace.

Front: What is sound in media language?
Back: Music, dialogue and sound effects used to create meaning.
A sign system used to communicate meaning.
Camera, editing and sound choices.
Objects or colours that suggest meanings.
Written language such as headlines, captions and slogans.
A typical feature of a media form or genre.
References to other media texts.
Something that communicates meaning.
The form of the sign, like an image or word.
The concept or meaning behind the sign.
The literal meaning of what is shown.
The suggested or implied meaning.
Text that guides the meaning of an image.
An over-simplified idea of a group.
The way media shows people, groups or ideas.
When a group appears rarely or not at all.
When a group is shown inaccurately or unfairly.
Choosing which aspects to show or hide.
Media shaping reality through editing and selection.
Beliefs and values shown in media.
Dominant beliefs presented as normal.
Beliefs that challenge dominant ideas.
Ideas about gender equality and representation of women.
A system where men hold power and women are limited.
Media that mixes styles, references and questions reality.
An organisation that produces and distributes media.
Media funded to provide information, education and entertainment.
The UK's main public service broadcaster.
Media funded mainly through advertising and profit.
A large company that owns many smaller companies.
One company controls production, distribution and exhibition.
One company buys other companies at the same level.
Different media products promoting each other.
Media platforms merging, like TV and online streaming.
Rules controlling what media can do.

Front: Who regulates UK TV and radio?
Back: Ofcom.
Legal protection for creative work.
A product expanded into sequels, spin-offs and merchandise.
How media products reach audiences.
Where and how media products are shown to audiences.
Online platforms for sharing content and interacting.
Content made by ordinary users, not institutions.
A social media user who affects audience choices.
A system that recommends content based on data.
Active audience communities supporting media products.
Audiences creating and sharing content.
Someone who is both producer and consumer.
Media-driven fear about behaviour threatening society.
Media messages injected into passive audiences.

Front: What is uses and gratifications theory?
Back: Audiences use media for needs like entertainment and information.

Front: What are the four uses and gratifications?
Back: Diversion, personal relationships, personal identity, surveillance.
Long-term media exposure shapes views of reality.
A period where media is largely online and interactive.
Different media technologies coming together.
A way to access media, like TV, radio or online.
Short trailer designed to create hype.
A promotional video showing highlights of a film or show.
A media product designed to sell or persuade.
Unique selling point that makes a product stand out.
The image and values a brand communicates.
A short memorable phrase used in marketing.
A short phrase promoting a brand or campaign.
A celebrity or influencer supporting a product.
A brand shown within a media text.

Front: What is a call to action?
Back: Text telling the audience what to do next.
Consistent design features used across a media brand.
How elements are arranged on a page or screen.
The title design at the top of a magazine.
Main text designed to grab attention.
Smaller heading giving more detail.
Text explaining an image.
Text on a magazine cover promoting content.
A highlighted quote designed to attract attention.
A set of colours used to create a consistent look.
The style and appearance of text.

Front: What is GCSE Media exam tip?
Back: Use correct terminology and link points to the question.
